appendix.title: Resources
appendix.para: There were many valuable sources of information that assisted in the creation of this book. The following sections list additional resources to help you learn even more &xml;.

listitem.para: The website http://www.xml.com/ is one of the most complete and timely sources of &xml; information and news around. It should be on your weekly reading list if you have any interest in learning or using &xml;.
Edited by Robin Cover, this is one of the largest and most up-to-date lists of &xml; resources. It can be found at http://www.oasis-open.org/cover/.
OASIS, the maintainers of DocBook, have a web page devoted to the &xml; application at http://www.oasis-open.org/docbook/. There, you will find the latest version and plenty of documentation.

varlistentry.term: A Tutorial on Character Code Issues, by Jukka Korpela

listitem.para: Signing up with the &xsl; mailing list is a great way to be informed of the latest developments in &xsl; and &xslt; tools and techniques. It's also a forum for asking questions and getting advice. The traffic is fairly high, so you should balance your needs with the high volume of messages that will be passing through your mailbox. To sign up, go to the web page http://www.mulberrytech.com/xsl/ and follow the instructions there for getting on the list.

This project is a part of the Apache project that focuses on XML technologies. It develops tools and technologies for using &xml; with Apache and provides feedback to standards organizations about &xml; implementations. Visit them at: http://xml.apache.org/
The Microsoft Developers Network's online workshop for &xml; and information about using &xml; with Microsoft applications. Visit them at: http://msdn.microsoft.com/xml/XMLGuide/
Articles, resources, opinions, news, and reviews covering all aspects of programming. Go to: http://www.ddj.com/ for online content, and subscribe to the magazine while you're there.

varlistentry.term: DocBook, the Definitive Guide, Norman Walsh and Leonard Muellner, O'Reilly & Associates.

listitem.para: DocBook is a popular and flexible markup language for technical documentation, with versions for &sgml; and &xml;. This book has an exhaustive, glossary-style format describing every element in detail. It also has lots of practical information for getting started using &xml; and stylesheets.

varlistentry.term: The &xml; Bible, Elliotte Rusty Harold, IDG Books Worldwide.

listitem.para: A solid introduction to &xml; and a comprehensive overview of the &xml; landscape.

varlistentry.term: &xml; in a Nutshell, Elliotte Rusty Harold and W. Scott Means, O'Reilly & Associates.

listitem.para: A comprehensive desktop reference for all things &xml;.

varlistentry.term: &html; and XHTML, the Definitive Guide, Chuck Musciano and Bill Kennedy, O'Reilly & Associates.

listitem.para: Updated with frequent new editions, this book is a very timely and comprehensive resource for learning about &html;.

varlistentry.term: Developing SGML DTDs: from Text to Model to Markup, by Eve Maler and Jeanne El Andaloussi, Prentice-Hall.

listitem.para: A step-by-step tutorial for designing and implementing DTDs.

varlistentry.term: The &sgml; Handbook, Charles F. Goldfarb, Oxford Press, 1995.

listitem.para: A very complete reference for &sgml;, including an annotated specification. Like its subject, the book is complex and hefty, so beginners may not find it to be a good introduction.

varlistentry.term: Java and &xml;, Brett McLaughlin, O'Reilly & Associates.

listitem.para: Shows how to put together &xml; and the Java programming language to build real-world applications.

varlistentry.term: Building Oracle &xml; Applications, Steve Muench, O'Reilly & Associates.

listitem.para: A worldwide federation of national standards organizations. Visit them at http://www.iso.ch/.
The World Wide Web Consortium at http://w3c.org/ oversees the specifications and guidelines for the technology of the World Wide Web.
The organization responsible for defining the Unicode character set. Visit them at: http://www.unicode.org/.

OASIS, the Organization for the Advancement of Structured Information Standards, is an international consortium that creates interoperable industry specifications based on public standards such as XML and SGML. Visit them at: http://www.oasis-open.org/.
The extraordinarily powerful text editor, and so much more. Learn all about it at: http://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/emacs.html.
A high-performance XSLT stylesheet processor. Fully implements XSLT and XLinks. Find out more about it at the Apache XML Project, http://xml.apache.org/.
A fully validating parser that implements XML, DOM levels 1 and 2, and SAX2. Find out more about it at the Apache XML Project, http://xml.apache.org/.
A Java implementation of XSLT. Get it at: http://www.jclark.com/xml/xt.html.

Starring the formidably-cute dust puppy and a gaggle of computer industry drones, this comic strip will inject much-needed jocularity into your bloodstream after a long day of hacking &xml;. The whole archive is available online at http://www.userfriendly.org/, and in two books by O'Reilly, User Friendly, the Comic Strip and Evil Geniuses in a Nutshell.

varlistentry.term: The Cathedral and the Bazaar, Eric S. Raymond, O'Reilly & Associates

listitem.para: In this philosophical analysis and evangelical sermon about the grassroots computer programming movement called Open Source, Raymond extols the virtues of community, sharing, and that good feeling you get when you're working for the common good.
